parts: Name this sculpture which stands in front of the Kluczynski Federal Building in Chicago’s Federal Plaza. This sculpture was painted using its artist’s namesake red color.
Flamingo is a stabile, which is contrasted with these kinetic sculptures consisting of moving elements suspended by wire.
This American sculptor is known for sculpting Flamingo as well as many mobiles.
Name these mathematical objects. These constructs are embeddings of a circle in three-dimensional space, and the simplest non-trivial one is the trefoil.
In 2020, Lisa Piccirillo proved that a knot named for this man is not a slice of a higher-dimensional knot. This English mathematician also invented a cellular automaton, his “Game of Life.”
Topologically, knots can be considered one-dimensional examples of these three-dimensional shapes. The surface area of this shape is given by the formula 4πr2 [“four pi r squared”].

answers: Charles André Joseph Marie de Gaulle
parts: Pearson won the 1957 Nobel Peace Prize for his role in resolving this crisis. This crisis started after Gamal Abdel Nasser nationalized an Anglo-French company that controlled a key waterway.

Pearson famously told this French President that “Canadians do not need to be liberated” in response to this man’s “Vive le Quebec Libre” speech at Expo 67. This man led the Free French during World War II.
Pearson was dubbed one of the “three wise men” of this international entity, which he helped found. Hastings Ismay was its first leader.
Name this South African-born author who also wrote The Life and Times of Michael K. He was the 2003 Nobel Laureate in Literature.
In this 1980 Coetzee novel, the Magistrate begins to question the colonialism of “The Empire.” He is later tortured by soldiers of the Third Bureau, a special forces unit led by Colonel Joll.

Coetzee’s Waiting for the Barbarians was inspired by an identically titled poem by Constantin Cavafy, a writer in this language. Cavafy’s poem Ithaca was inspired by an epic poem in this language, The Odyssey.

answers: The Love for Three Oranges [accept The Love of the Three Oranges or L’Amour des trois oranges]
parts: Name this ballet. A strong pulsating brass beat accompanies a dramatic string melody in the “Dance of the Knights”, which appears in this ballet.
Romeo and Juliet is a ballet by this Russian composer, who also composed a work meant to teach children about instruments titled Peter and the Wolf.
The evil witch Fata Morgana puts the title curse on the Prince after he laughs at her clumsiness in this opera by Prokofiev based on a Carlo Gozzi play.

answers: Tsiolkovsky rocket equation [accept classical rocket equation or ideal rocket equation]
linear momentum [do not accept or prompt on angular momentum]
parts: Name this equation, which states that the maximum change in velocity is equal to the effective exhaust velocity times the natural log of the mass ratio.
A rocket can accelerate forward by expelling part of its mass backward with high velocity, a result of the conservation of this quantity, which applies to both elastic and inelastic collisions.
Since a rocket’s mass changes during flight, it cannot be modeled by the statement force equals mass times acceleration, which is the second of this man’s three laws of motion.
The desert being referred to is this one, which is named for the Mexican state whose borderlands with Arizona the Tohono O’Odham inhabit.
Pima County derives its name from the Spanish name for the related Akimel O’Odham people. This city, the home of the University of Arizona, is the county seat of Pima County.
The third group that speaks the O’Odham language, the Hia Ced O’Odham, live along this river that flows from its namesake US state through the Hoover Dam into the Gulf of California.

answers: abortion (prompt on “birth control” or similar answers)
parts: Levitt, one of Freakonomics’ coauthors, is an economist at this institution, which names a school of economic thought contrasted with the saltwater school. Milton Friedman once taught at this institution.

In Freakonomics, Levitt builds off of research he conducted with Donohue relating the legalization of this practice to crime rates. Levitt used the example of a Romanian ban on this practice to argue that its legalization reduced crime.

Freakonomics has sometimes been criticised as an “amateur” work of this academic field, which focuses on the study of social interactions and structures. Emile Durkheim created Rules for its “method.”
Name this phenomenon in which a liquid produces an insulating vapor layer when it comes close to a sufficiently hot surface. A few drops of water can skitter across a hot pan due to this effect.
The Leidenfrost effect can also allow you to blow out a mouthful of this substance. This fluid, which boils at 77 kelvin, is frequently used in cryogenics or biological storage.
The insulating vapor layer produced by the Leidenfrost effect further prevents this process in which a liquid turns into a gas.
In the Ramayana, this figure set fire to the city of Lanka using his tail. He brings a healing herb to Lakshmana by moving an entire mountain.
In Greek myth, this Titan brought fire to humanity in a fennel stalk. As punishment, he was chained to a rock to be eternally tortured, but was eventually freed by Heracles.
This kami died while giving birth to the fire kami Kagutsuchi. In grief, her husband beheaded Kagutsuchi and split his body into eight pieces that became eight volcanoes.

answers: First Barons’ War [prompt on Barons’ War]
Edward I [accept Edward Longshanks; prompt on Edward]
parts: Identify this war that was started by several rebellious landowners. It was ended by the Treaty of Lambeth.
This English King’s incompetent leadership and despotism sparked the revolt of the barons. In the middle of the war, this king, who was nicknamed “Lackland,” died of dysentery in 1216.

John’s son Henry III fought the Second Barons’ War and was captured at Lewes. However, this son of Henry defeated the barons at Evesham and released his father. This man would later be known as the “Hammer of the Scots.”

answers: canon [Accept canon quartet, anti-prompt on round]
parts: Name this character who sings the “Gravedigging Duet” with the prison warden Rocco before saving her husband.
In Fidelio, Marzelline, Leonore, Rocco, and Fidelio sing “Mir ist so Wunderbar”, a quartet of this form. Pieces in this form involve a main melody being introduced at regular intervals.
Fidelio is the only opera by this composer, whose other works include the “Eroica” symphony and the “Moonlight” Sonata.

could not forgive himself if [he] [makes] others as miserable as [he] made [himself]”. For 10 points each, [10] Name this short story. The husband of this story’s narrator threatens to send her to the physician Weir Mitchell, who actually treated this short story’s author with the rest cure.
This author wrote “The Yellow Wallpaper.” She also wrote about Jeff, Van, and Terry discovering an all-female society in Herland.
Gilman’s text Women and Economics is considered a leading text of this philosophical and social movement. In the text, Gilman advocates for the economic independence and specialization of women.

answers: metaphase I [Accept any answer indicating the first metaphase; prompt on just metaphase]
parts: Name this process of cell division contrasted with mitosis.
In this stage of meiosis, paired homologous chromosomes align along the center of the cell. Note: Number is required.

These protein complexes bring together homologous chromosomes, allowing for crossing over to occur. This complex forms during the zygotene stage of prophase I [one] and disappears after the pachytene stage.

answers: Bear Flag Republic [or California Republic; prompt on California]
California Gold Rush [or the Gold Rush of 1849; prompt on Gold Rush]
parts: Name this polity, whose first and only leader was William B. Ide.
After he arrived in Sonoma, this “Pathfinder” gave his support for the Bear Flag Republic. He would later lose to James Buchanan in 1856 as the first Republican Presidential candidate.

The Bear Flag Revolt took place 2 years before this event, which started when Samuel Brannan discovered the namesake precious metal at Sutter’s Mill. Levi Strauss may have started selling Jeans during this event.
Identify this character, a friend of Sir Charles Cartwright, who appears prominently in the novel Three Act Tragedy. He often uses his “little grey cells” to great effect.

Hercule Poirot reveals that he knows Dr. James Sheppard committed the title crime in this novel. This novel is written as Sheppard’s personal account, and its epilogue is revealed to be his suicide note.
This British Dame created the character of Hercule Poirot and wrote The Murder of Roger Ackroyd. She also wrote The Mousetrap, And Then There Were None, and The Murder on the Orient Express.

answers: Gerald Lynn Bostock v. Clayton County, Georgia
parts: Name this 2020 Supreme Court case, whose plaintiff, a child welfare coordinator, who the court ruled had been discriminated against based on his participation in a gay recreational softball league.
The majority opinion in Bostock was written by this conservative justice. He was appointed by President Trump to replace the late Justice Antonin Scalia in 2017.
This justice dissented with Justice Alito, claiming the court was revising Title VII to “better reflect the current values of society.” He was accused of sexual harassment by Anita Hill.

answers: Six Characters in Search of an Author
parts: Name this character who is summoned by hanging coats and hats on racks since she follows the “articles of her trade."
Madame Pace appears in this play in which a rehearsal of Mixing it Up is interrupted by the title figures. The final scene of this play features The Child drowning in a fountain.
This Italian playwright of Henry IV wrote Six Characters in Search of an Author.
Name this online multiplayer social deduction game released by InnerSloth, where up to ten players can play on the Skeld, Mira HQ, or Polus.
Players of Among Us are split into crewmates and players with this role. Players with this role can either sabotage, vent, or kill, and their goal is to eliminate all the crewmates.

During the Game Awards 2020, Innersloth announced this new Among Us map due to release in early 2021. Players will be able to choose the room that they spawn in after meetings in this map, and the Gap Room on this map contains ladders and a moving platform.

answers: Mexico [or United Mexican States, or Estados Unidos Mexicanos]
parts: The “Bird-Man Burial” was a major find in this ancient city. This city’s Mound 34 contains the only known remains of a Mississippian copper workshop.

The title of Bird-Man in this society was given to the first person to find a sooty tern egg. These people used the Rongorongo script, and several of their famous monolithic statues wear hat-like Pukao.

The Great Pyramid of Cholula in this country remained a major cult center of the feathered deity Quetzalcoatl even after its invasion by Hernan Cortez. Other ancient sites in this modern-day country include Teotihuacan and Chichen Itza.
